title: Have you ever wanted to be or identify yourself with any of the characters you have created in your books? What character is it? And why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I identify with all my characters. The flawed heroes are me; characters wanting to be excellent but falling short before picking themselves up. The tortured villains are me; characters full of some sort of rage that needs to be made sense of. The secondary characters who work behind the counter of a fast food restaurant were me in a younger life. The narrator is me, older and looking down on it all wondering if all the emotion if worth it. If my characters didn’t have part of me in them their voices would be flat, their motivations rote and there would be no point of view.

I’ve actually almost always identified myself with characters in my story. I feel like it gives my characters the depth and emotion that readers love. Identifying yourself with a character allows you to put yourself in the character’s shoes and just use your own experiences and past to shape the character. For example, one of such characters is named Ying. She’s bubbly and fun but there’s another side to her which people don’t often see. Being someone who’s a happy pill most of the time, I think people get this impression that my life is all fairytale and joy. Life goes on, I’m innocent and naive. But, I think people don’t realize that I’ve gone through A LOT of hardships, been cheated, lied and backstabbed before. The reason why I’m happy, though, is because I don’t remind myself of the bad times. I remind myself to move on. Creating Ying and using my experiences as a backstory for her really allows me to make the story more realistic. She’s not a ‘perfect’ girl. Being happy doesn’t mean being ‘quirky’.

This is Astor.  Astor is a personification of the darker side of my personality. I think all writers identify with all the characters they’ve created on some level, but Astor is specifically meant to be a self-insert. I’m not even sure where to begin with him. Astor began as one of many personas that I adopted inside my head. Being a writer, I tend to see the world through the eyes of various characters, but every couple of years there was one who I identified closely with myself and made into a kind of internal identity. Astor was originally just a slightly edgier, cockier version of me. But Astor had a mind of his own. For one thing, I didn’t name him. He told me his name, firmly. I decided very little about his appearance — I think his violet cat eyes were the only thing I actively chose to give him, and the black hair and pale skin were a given. But I didn’t decide to give him long hair, even though now I couldn’t imagine him without it. I already knew what he looked like before finding the above image, and so far, the above image is the most spot-on one that I’ve come across. That’s pretty much exactly what he looks like. Astor is basically a concentrated embodiment of all the aspects of myself that, at some point in my life, I refused to acknowledge. I associate him with my Shadow archetype in the Jungian sense (although obviously he’s a combined Shadow/animus). When I was first building Astor as a character, I thought that arrogance was the root of all evil (and proceeded to lose all my self-confidence as a result), so Astor is completely full of himself. He is a prince and likes to be worshipped by his subjects. I find it impossible to simply relax and enjoy my life, so Astor is hedonistic, indulging in every sensual pleasure of his palace. I was uncomfortable with my own sexuality during the first half of puberty, so Astor is carnal and licentious, and an incubus-like nocturnal creature that seduces women. In my mid-teens, I was a complete rebel without a cause, obsessed with the idea of free will and individualism. Astor is a tyrant, delighting in subjugation and domination. Throughout the last decade, I’ve had to work through all of these individual qualities and become comfortable with them. The version of Astor that I’m writing has some redeeming qualities to balance all that out. I’ve given him my sense of empathy. His character arc is based around his fear of his future responsibilities as king, and his genuine desire to be a good king for his people without collapsing under the stress. He’s still an anti-hero, and his appearance and mannerisms evoke the most stylish and decadent of villains, but he’s a better person than he gives himself credit for. Writing him has helped me to learn more about myself and embrace the darkness within. He’s absolutely my favorite character I’ve ever written, and by far the most personal. I love him so much.

I can’t say I want to be any of my major characters but there is a schoolteacher I invented for my first novel who did something I long to do: purchase a flat in the impressive Landmark condominium, a red brick building at the center of Tarrytown which had formerly been a school and before that a farm. Scholars say the farm was the model for the Van Tassel home in The Legend of Sleepy Hollow. Apartments begin at 500,000 and there is no pool, no sauna and no tennis court, just a magnificent lawn with a WW I monument. I live above it in a prewar co-op. The main character of my latest novel Blooded in Sleepy Hollow has the Catholicism Inleft begins. I envy her strong swimming ability but not her conscience. Her husband creates video games for a living and seems like fun. I think well-created characters are too complex to be emulated. There would always be a downside. Thank you for a really good question.

Raptor, the Merciless Eagle.  Raptor is a bounty hunter and mercenary the protagonist meets during the events of To Be Forever. Described as an “imposing, scar-covered man,” who was “bald, and clear, blue, predatory eyes.” Raptor certainly fits the bill for a soldier of fortune. But he wasn’t always a mercenary and Raptor isn’t even his true name. Raptor was a criminal whose life was spared when he was finally caught. Most people wanted to see Raptor dead after his capture but mysteriously he only had to serve a relatively lenient sentence for his crimes. Once he served his time, he decided to start working as a mercenary under the alias Raptor. His bravery and “it is just business” mentality caused him to be known as “The Merciless Eagle”. I’m nothing like Raptor. Growing up, I didn’t have a father figure until I was in high school. I was cowardly, meek, and risk-averse. In my life, I always looked up to my coaches and the chefs I worked under as they pushed me out of my comfort zone and encouraged me to take risks. Before The Adventurer and Raptor part ways, Raptor says something that made me believe the characters in books can truly come alive. “I can see it in your eyes, kid—- you really are after something, aren’t you? Something to make you feel alive? That’s what everyone wants. For me, I’ve wanted to feel alive all my life. The only times I do are in battle, when I’m bloodied and close to death. In those moments, fighting for my life, I feel truly alive. Between those moments. I’d be better off dead. I’d prefer my life to be like the brilliant strike of lightning, rather than the long, untroubled burning of a candle. Lightning, while fleeting, is exciting. It burns gloriously and leaves all who see it amazed, stupefied even. I look at a candle for the same fleeting moment after lighting it, and that is it. No wonder, no exhilaration. It may burn for an eternity but what does it matter? Go out there and live like lightning, kid.” Raptor embodies a lot of what I wanted to be when I was a kid. I wanted to be brave. I wanted to be able to take risks. I wanted to be able to do awesome, once in a lifetime things. But For a while, I was too cowardly. Too weak. While I don’t want to become a bounty hunter or warrior now, I have been blessed to have teachers in my life that have pushed me to take risks and chase after my goals fervently. Live like lightning. I don’t believe I wrote that, in a sense. It is just what Raptor said while I was writing and without a lot of what he embodied in the novel, I probably wouldn’t have written it in the first place. Thanks for the A2A. “So, you finally built up the courage to tell me to stop, huh? There is some hope for you yet,” - Raptor  To Be Forever - Kindle edition by Angel Santiago, Stephen Green, Logan Slominski, Rosalind Stanley. Literature & Fiction Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com.

I have a character named Briar Rose Grimsgaard. She is half-black half-white, Jewish like her dad, and very, very goth. She is into vampires and werewolves and horror movies, loves fantasy, and despite her appearance is actually quite friendly, if not overly theatrical with a love for dramatic entrances where she blasts Phantom of the Opera from her Bluetooth speaker. She is strong, confident, happy with herself, and not afraid to stand up for what she thinks is right. I would totally want to be her friend in real life. Sometimes, when I sit and think about her, I get disappointed that she isn’t a real person and I can’t actually talk to her. It would be so great sometimes; she would always put me in a good mood and probably would help give me plenty of ideas for my writing.

I made a character who was a princess in a fantasy kingdom based off of medieval France. It followed her through her childhood into her adulthood to when she manipulates the political system to take the power from behind her weaker husband with the help of her advisor. When she’s an adult, she has a much stronger character than me - I don’t see hardly any of me in her. When I wrote out her childhood scenes, though, I took a lot of it from stories that my family members would tell me and from what I remembered to create her character then. Having no children of my own, sometimes I struggle to write children characters and they end up being extremely mature for their age. So, I made her what I had been - a spoiled brat. She throws tantrums, she berates her servants, her tutor smacks her at one point when she goes overboard, she breaks things, and she’s just an unholy terror. (No, I wasn’t THAT bad, but exaggeration often has a better effect.) When she’s a teenager, she’s incredibly dramatic, naive in her perception of the world (much like many teenagers are), and impulsive to a fault - much like I was as a teenager. Besides that, though, at her core, she is her own character and entirely unlike me. Her growth and her experiences are some that I, as a common pleb, would not go through. I wanted her to grow from tragedy in the male-dominated political system, which is how her character develops to be so strong and intelligent in the future.

Of course. In fact, I believe most writers begin creating characters through their wish to be someone else. One of my first characters-or at least, the ones I spend many time and effort in creating-was a girl in my novel Drifting Around: a novel that I'm still writing. Hailee Morgan was a fearless, fearsome creature. Unafraid to do anything she wanted, couldn't be caring less about what people said about her. I had-and still have, sometimes-problems with minding too much to other people's opinions and thoughts about me, which leads me to be afraid to do so many things I want to carry out. So I put the reverse personality that I so wished I had on Her. Aside from the not-caring personality, Hailee also had the ability to wield words right back at her opponent, causing the bully or the critic to shut down. This was another one of my wishing personality. I am a good writer, but a poor in-the-moment speaker. I absolutely sucked at making my points to someone, or standing up for someone, even myself. But Hailee could say the right works at the right time and fight back people just the discreet way that seemed not like provoking. Apart from all these, Hailee was also very good at skateboarding, a dream I could not accomplish because I lived in a third world country which did not have the right type of streets and equipment to skateboard. I used to skateboard well when I lived in London, but now I had to move back in Bangladesh. So combining all the points, I wouldn't wait to trade places with Hailee in a heartbeat. I really wish she existed.

I’m able to identify with most characters I’ve created to varying degrees and for a wide variety of reasons. Too many characters and for too many reasons for me to get into fully, but I’ll try to give one or two examples. The main character of one story I’m writing, who has the alias of Vegas (I haven’t settled upon a name for him yet) is one that I identify with only to a limited degree. We have some common aspects, but mostly he is everything that I could have been had I made the opposite decisions in a number of circumstances. The best way I can think to describe it is the episode of Futurama where the characters meet alternate versions of themselves. While they look very similar, most of their differences came down to decisions that were made by tossing a coin. So with Vegas, he is essentially the “tails” side of the coin, and I am the “heads” side. If I had called tails, I would be Vegas, and if he called heads, he would be me. Then there’s Mako Kirisaki, another character from a very different story. I identify quite strongly with him. We share similar protective instincts, we have similar levels of tenacity, we have similar tendencies to isolate ourselves from other people (albeit for different reasons), we each get dumped with burdens that weigh heavily upon us. There are other similarities too but this answer’s pretty long as it is so I’ll stop there.

I think most writers identify with portions of their characters because the easiest personality traits to translate into a character are those we know best: ourselves. This is also where we deviate from ourselves into traits that we do not ourselves have. So, I have a primary OC in some of my writing who wears jeans and t-shirts and boots and has a primary residence in the same state I live in, all things I like. And the character is female. There the resemblance ends as she is also a talented covert agent bound to the earth goddess … Yep, total fantasy there. <laughter> Other characters care about some of the things I do: equality in the world for everyone, not being racist, education for people, etc. But, they are not me and I am not, save for getting them out into the world, them. <chuckle>

Heya, thanks for the A2A. Absolutely! When I first started writing, all the characters were based on me and my friend group. It was much easier to write when I just had to figure out what they would do, and move forward from there. Obviously I changed them slightly, made them what we wished we could be if we were in that situation. Part of me still, as I write, want to be my main female character. I think I write main characters similar to what I would want to be. That or I would just love to live there lives. But I think that's kind of the point. I write stories that I would want to read, that I would want to be the heroine of. I’m trying to branch out and work on other character types, but it’s actually rather difficult.

What a damn good question. Yes, I have! In the last three years more than ever. And the character I chose is not even a male. It is a young female surgeon called Moira. Moira is a genius in her job, but she’s highly bipolar. And although I’m not in the least attracted by her bipolar disorder, what seduced me of Moira is her nerve, tenacity, focus and grit when she wants to achieve her goals. In the early chapters of the novel where I introduced her, she even risked taking her own life to obtain what she wanted. And she succeeded. I mean in accomplishing her mission, not losing her life, which she kept. She’s ready to go all in when she wants something and no obstacle is too big for her. The flip side of it all, though, is that she’s a mess in relationships, and this is a trait we actually share. So when someone dumps her or does her wrong, she breaks down a lot, and that makes me sad. I feel for Moira. The curious thing is that she shouldn’t even exist in the novel; as a character, she appeared once, in an early version of the current story and was not supposed to be seen again. She ended up being one of the bad guys, even if she played more in the grey zone, so you don’t know if, the next time, she will be helping the MC or kick him in the abyss.

A lot of authors put little pieces of themselves into their characters, and many experiences that the characters go through the author has experienced as well. My friend and I wanted to write a story just for fun. It was going to be about our experiences online and the things we had to learn the hard way. We created fictional main characters that represented each of us. My friend's character didn't represent her exactly, but was more of an alternate reality version of her—like what she might be like if she hadn't been raised the way she had. However, my character (Holly) was almost exactly like me. She would experience nearly everything I had, with some exceptions. For example, she had social media (which I don't have), went to a public school (which I don't attend), and had workaholic parents (which I don't have). Holly is now becoming her own character with her own personality, but originally she was almost exactly like me. I identify with a lot of my characters, but I identify most with Holly, because I'm able to relate on an emotional level AND on a personal experience level.

Of course. The characters I create in my books are all based off myself, some more so than others. They say write what you know, and the person I know best is myself. I identify with my characters because they are, in some aspects, me. I give this one my insecurities, that one my friendliness, that one my humor… Basically my book is less of a sci-fi/fantasy and more of an autobiography (not really). There are also characters in my book that I want to be because I write them to be better than myself. Of course, none of them are perfect; they all have their flaws, but they each have their own redeeming qualities as well. Of all of my characters, I would say I want to be the most confident one. She can be a (excuse my language) b*tch sometimes, but she’s loyal and cares deeply about the people she loves. Just as a note, I do give my characters other personalities than my own. I don’t know how great a book would be if all the characters had the same personalities and characteristics (and especially if they all had my personality, there would be no one cool and everyone would never talk). Write what you know, but you should also research so you know more and you can write with some variety.

It’s a bit more nuanced than that. I don’t want to be any of my characters, because then I wouldn’t know the whole story – not to mention the fact that most characters end up going through hell at some stage of their arc. But there’s usually a significant piece of my identity in my characters. So as much as I want to be some massive hero, I know that’s not my role. My characters are me, even if I will never be my characters. That’s a little weird–sounding but you get the idea.

Many of the characters in the novels I have written are based on me. They are riffs on my own character and personality. In my work The Streets of London, I had three main characters. They were all me but each one represented a different aspect of me. Had I made a single character most readers would have been unable to accept the portrayal; they would have thought no one person cold have so many different aspects to their personality. Each of the three characters was in effect an avatar of me. In fiction and creative writing we use ourselves as models for our invented characters. All novels are autobiographical.

I’m not crazy about blatant self-insertion, however, my main character does reflect some of my traits, and others that I’m deficient in. I think most of us put something of ourselves into our characters, both positive and negative aspects. It makes the character more human and allows us to use the broad spectrum of emotion we ourselves are familiar with. We know what loss, pain, love, disappointment, self-doubt, hope feels like. Why not tap into that and take it a step beyond. It would be a wasted resource if we ignored ourselves in our writing.

I try to ensure the characters I have created have something I can identify with as it make it easier to write them believably. For example, one of my characters is very protective of her younger brother, willing to do not-so-nice things to ensure he is safe. I relate to this because my own experience with my siblings. Writing what you know allows for believability but I’ve never wished I was any of the characters I’ve created.

I suppose a bit of myself is in every character I write, but heavily identify with? Not necessarily. I typically write parts of me, or parts of me that I want to become, but each character also takes on their own persona as I am writing in the flow of the book. I do like the characters that can speak their minds without fear of consequence, as I suppose that is something I long to do, but cannot always do based on circumstance :)

My main series character, Dan Sullivan, is basically a fictionalized self-portrait. His backstory is very similar to mine. His career path is similar to mine. Many of the short stories, and the only novel to this point, are based on things that happened to me. But, at the same time, Dan’s handsomer, smarter, braver, wittier, does better with the ladies (not that much better, but still). So he’s me with improvements. Or perhaps he’s the me I’m striving to be.

I identify with all of my main characters. Each of them is built around aspect of my own personality which becomes the lens that influences their dialogue, thoughts and actions. Sometimes I give in to the temptation to write myself into a book. The first time I did this was in my fantasy novel The Misbegotten King. The character is named Dierdre M’callister and she is the leader of a Scottish-based clan who is loyal to the king despite enmity between their families.

Of course. She is Mayuri. Mayuri is the protagonist in my first novel, “Vilapa Dena Govipole Vikramaya” (The Adventure of the Moaning Farm) Mayuri is a 15-years-old girl who has an Australian origin. Absolutely, I haven't an Australian origin, but I felt that may better help for developing the story. It worked. She is brave, thinkable, friendly and helpful. She interests in investigating because she had read many detective stories. So, her character was very same to me. (But I'm not too helpful 😉) Thanks for A2A.

Any character I have ever written and fleshed out has a small piece of me. Some are HORRENDOUS villains (let’s face it, there is darkness in every Human, me included), some are peace-loving teachers, some are hell-bent-for-leather action junkies. Some I REALLY WANT to be. Others have situations so bad that I would not wish them on my worst enemy.

I find my comic book character Jay Wylde to be quite interesting in the fact that although I’ve taken all my worst traits, amplified them, stuffed them in a character, given her a really bad backstory and billions of years to brood, she’s actually an ok character. She’s the better version of me I guess. Liked by many but also hated by others. She’s smart and funny and selfless. :)

Yes, sure. When I wrote about my main protagonist, I referred to an MBTI personality profile - the INTP, since I’m also an INTP. Different, name, different era, different job and expertise, but I based her profile, and her personality through my own experiences. I had to imagine a lot though, and how she would react when she was was challenged in life threatening situations. The well known author of Divergent - Veronica Roth - also developed her characters according to personality theory as well.

Not everyone who writes knows spies, and military operatives, and SEALs. For sure, not every author knows them well enough to write about their exploits in the Code Raven Series. Nor would a female author admit to her sexy and somewhat sex-crazed main characters like Mia in Target in the Sun and Layla in Lie to Me: an expose on sex for money, are actually parts of her own life/personality/desires. I’m afraid I cannot answer that question on the grounds that it might incriminate me!

In my book Under Fire, The wife’s name was Bea, she was such a loving and caring wife and mother to her wayward husband. She had great attributes in personality as well as physical attributes! I created her based on yours truly, and the attributes that I possess.. I am BEA! Regards, Author Dia Stone

Never wrote any books - only fanfiction. And I only want to identify with those that are less like me in appearance, regardless of positive body images and stuff, why? Because it’s fun to pretend and make your own characters.
Yes. To create characters, I basically split my personality in little tiny pieces, so I identify with all of my characters because I can relate to them in some way. Cheers, T.N
Not specifically. However, to some degree I thin every writer identifies themselves to a particular character in the book they are writing at the time. All the best.
